div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,393] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, JANUARY 15, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.
Throw Steel Nibs Away!
They waste time, are costly to use, wear out, scratch, etc.
Try a "Swan" Fountain Pen.
Prices from 10/6
Sold by all Stationers and Importers in Cairo and Alexandria.
Catalogue free.
Mable, Todd & Bard, High Holborn, London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Pacific Line of Royal Mail Steamers.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES FROM MAY TO OCTOBER INCLUSIVE.
OUTWARDS to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Orentes" will leave Suez about February 9
R.M.S "Oruba" will leave Suez about January 19.
HOMEWARDS to NAPLES MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY
R.M.S. "Oretava" will leave Port Said about January 29
R.M.S. “Oriest" will leave Port Said about January 26
Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within 8 months of arrival.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all information apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT-SAID & PORT-TEWFIK (Suez) 31-12-904

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL STEAMERS.
div.p: Special Reduced Rates During Summer Season,
OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON. Departures from Suez.
S.S. Derbyshire 6,635 tons, leaves about January 18.
S.S. Lancashire 4,244 tons, leaves about February 1.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Worcestershire 7,160 tons, leaves about January 22.
S.S. Yorkshire 4,196 tons leaves about February 5.
FARES from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0, London £17.0.0, Colombo £32.10.0, Rangoon £37.10.0.
Agents Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Thursday, January 18, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday 20th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO’s LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for LONDON or LIVERPOOL direct.
(Electric Light.) SALOON (Amidships) FARE £12. (Latest improvements.)
S.S. RANGOON 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about Januray 25 for London.
S.S. BURMA 5600 Tons will leave PORT SAID about February 1 for London.
S.S. ARRACAN 5800 Tons will leave PORT SAID about February 15 for Liverpool
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 12 days thereafter.
Apply WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;
G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: WHITE STAR LINE.
div.p: NEW YORK AND BOSTON MEDITERRANEAN SERVICE.

Regular Sailings between Alexandria , Naples, and Boston or New York, U.S.A. By the large modern twin screw steamers CELTIC, 21,000 tons- REPUBLIC, 15,400 tons- CANOPIC, 13,000 tons- ROMANIC, 11,400 tons.

Regular Service between Italy and United States throughout the year. Excellent accommodation for all classes of passengers. For plans of steamers, rates of passengers between the various ports, and full particulars, apply to THOS, COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd., Cairo, Alexandria, Luxor and Assouan; John Ross & Co., Alexandria; White Star Line, Via Roma, Gena, and 21, Piazza della Borsa, Naples.

GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s’occupe de l’achat et de la vente d'effets sur l’Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-904

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste

(Departures from Suez) To Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobé about January 3 and January 17. To Aden, Karachi, and Bombay accelerated service about January 31. To Aden, Karachi, Bombay, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about December 8.
East African Line.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: GRAND HOTEL BONNARD, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: 2s. PER DAY. WINE INCLUDED.

First class open all year. Thoroughly innovated and improved. Standing in a magnificent position in its own extensive grounds on the banks of the Blue Nile. Perfect elimate, no mosquitos, modern comfort, very homely. Concerts twice a week on the verandah of the hotel. 22855-16.7

First Class Family Hotel with Every Modern Comfort.
Unique Situation on the Beach.
Lovely Garden. Lawn Tennis. Large Terrace. Electric Light. Sea Baths. Own springs. Perfect sanitary arrangements. Stables for horses and carriages.
Moderate Charges. -- Special terms for Government Officials and Officers of the Army of Occupation.
G. RUNCKEWITZ, Proprietor.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: First-class Hotel. Situated in Rosetta Avenue, the finest quarter in the Town. Two mintes from Railway Station. Close to Conservatory and the Opera House. Lift. Electric Light Throughout. Perfect Sanitary Arrangements. Magnificent Ball, Reception, Reading, and Music Rooms. Bar and Smoking Room.
HENRI CHAMOULLEAU, Proprietor.
FINE TERRACE ON THE AVENUE. - SPLENDID GARDEN. - OMNIBUS MEET ALL TRAINS AND STEAMERS. 28-26

div.head: EASTERN EXCHANGE HOTEL, PORT SAID.
div.p: First Class Hotel. Modern in all respects.
Fire-proof, Drained to the Sea, Lifts, Electric Light, English and French Billiards, Fresh and Salt Water Baths.
The Coolest Summer Residence in Egypt.
Special terms to Cairo Residents and their families desirous of enjoying the cool air and sea bathing during the summer months.
Dragomans in Hotel Uniform Meet all Trains and Steamers.

The George Nungovich Hotels

M»: ONB PIASTRE TARIFF.
THB ELECTION.
The extraordinary defeat of the ex Prime
Minieter at Manoheetsr and the raoent greet
Liberal gaine look at though the polling
i« going etrong egeinet the Uoioniata. Bat
it maet be remembered that the Liberal-
Labour party hu a great many vietorie* yet
to win, for in order to gain a majorityjof
fifty orer Unionieta and Nationaliita, the
party mint perform the almost enpeibnman
feat of oaptnring no fewer than 172 aeetr,
ooonting 341 rotee on a diviaion. Thia, ex-
travagant aa it appeara, ia actually forty
votes lower than the foraoaet of Mr. W. T.
Stead, who prediotad a turnover of 192 aeata,
ooonting 384 on a diviaion. Wo now traoe the
fluctuation in the voting aineo the General
Eleotion of 1895 :
In 1895 Unioniat polling wee 12 pet oent. higher
then Anti-Unioniat.
in 1895 1900 Unioniat polling waa 3J per cent
lower than Anti-Unioniat.
In 1900 Unioniat polling waa 12 per oent
higher than Anti-Unioniat.
In 1903-1905 Unioniat polling waa 12 per oe .L
lower than Anti-Unioniat
Prom thia table it ia clear that if by polling
were a direct index to General Election polling
—and thia ia the aasnmption upon which the
'a Liberal-loboar majority hare
admittedly baenfonndal—theUnioniatGovern-
would have beeo beaten in 1900 by a Jj
par oent majority of the electorate. A* it waa,
the 3| per oent minority waa converted into a
12 per oent majority—a turnover of 15J per
oent in eU. Thia 15| per oent, in feet i» the
figure of diaoonnt to ba allowed for enti-
Ministerial biae. If evente follow in 1906 the
fiairly regular oonrae they have taken einw
1895—and there ia nothing to ahow that they
will not do ao—the 12 per oent by eleotion
Unioniat minority will be oonverted into a 3|
lieroent General Eleotion Unioniat m.jority.
'Pnia would give the Unioniat party a rmdl
majority of perhapa thirty aeata in Great
Britain only. Aaaaming that Ireland returns
eighty-two Nationaliet and twenty one Unionist
ibera, the Unionist party would be left in
lority in the Hoaae of Commons of thirty-
-the Government majirity being oompiwe 1
of Liberal, Labour, and Nationa'iet members. This oalonlation opens the way to a number

of possibilities, all of oncimmon interest. In the first plaoe, the majority of (spproximately) thirty-one ia the highest majority which Sir Henry Campbell Bannerman oan hope for, aa attested by Liberal atatistioa—on lose the oonrae of politioel fooling in the oonntry ia to be com pletely diverts! from ita eoooatomed channel. If the Prime Miniater oan perform thia feat, he may obtain a majority of perhapa eixty mem- bera. Will be do ao I In the light of the eventa of the laat few daya there ia no wairant for supposing that it ia impossible.
BRITISH AND GERMAN TRADE.
Some interesting statiatioa aa to German
trade are given by Sir Benjamin Kidd, a most
oompetent authority on all eooh matters, in a
letter to the "Timee,” oovering the period
1900-1906. In the first-named year, we held
an advantage of sixty millions sterling over
Germany in the aggregate valne of exports
and imports. By 1904—the German statistic
for last year are not yet poMiehed—onr
rival bed so gained ground at to redace
tfceBritiah lead by jest 88pereeot, aetrik

five yeaie. If Oensaap oootiasee to gain gnsadatths aaas.paee, the sod rf another dsoada will bring with it eqaality between the two natiooe in foreign boeiosee. There ii no nseon. nonorsr. whp that ahoold not oocnr in duo oonrrs, nnlan ws raeort to rsprieali for the boantiee, ebipping eabeidiee, and heavy da tin on British nsanafootaras wbioh the K.iier employ* eo taeoenfoUy. Tbs more favourable •tatiitiea of onr foreign eommsres laat yetr ate no tme criterion rf a peimanent improvement; the chtnge for the batter synchronised w th the arrangement ofpeaoi between Japan and Rouia, and with tba renewed activity nf Lancashire1! itaple indnitry. Bat Germuy continued fo filch borinese from Bagland at an

div.p:
local and general.
Deutsche Orient Bank.
The Alexandria branch of the Deutsche Orient Bunk has been at work since the 3rd in*t.. and the branch at Cairo will be estab­lished short’y.
Fire at Alexandria.
Fire broke out yesterday in a farniture shop belonging to Mursi Ambar, in the Sonk El Kanto, and was extinguished by the Fire- Bri< ide. The damage has . not yet been estimated.
French Chamber of Commerce.
The December number of the Bulletin of the French Chamber of Commerce of Alex- I audria contaius an analysis of the Financial Adviser’s Note, aud amass of usefal informa­tion on Egypt's financial and commercial progress.
Egyptian Enterprise Co.
On the 15th October M. Toussaint Canerd sold to the Egyptian Enterprise and Develop­ment Co. for £350,00 a quantity of land at Boulac. On Friday last this identical piece of land was rosold by the company for £61.500.
The Municipal Elections.
It will not be iuopportnne to remind those of our readers who are not on the lists of voters for the Alexandria Munioipal elections, that they have only np to the 1st inst. to apply, if ter that date no application for the municipal franchise can be entertained.
In a Few Months.
To obtaiu in a short time a result which formerly often requited long months of study, such is the advantage the Berlitz cJchool offers, which explains its universal success. Berlitz School of Languages : A exandria, 26, Rue de V Eg baa Copte; Cairo 1, Sharia KameL [Advt.] The Kahil Property.
It is announce 1 that Mme Veuve Kahil Pacha rtfuses to sell her property and garden iu the Ismailia quarter of Cairo for L.E. 105,(kO. Some companies have offered even up to L.E. 170,000 in annual payments for this property, but these offers have not been entertained.
Mother and Daughter Asphyxiated,
Ou a ould night, a few days ago, a native womau and her daughter, of Kafr Sakr, went to bed iu a dosed room with a charcoal fire, lu the morning the mother and daughter we e found dead in their beds. The post-mortem examination showed that death was due to suffocation.
Alexandria's Tranquillity.
The celebration of Greek New Year’s Day passed off very quietly. Every precaution had been taken by the Alexandria City Police to cope with any disturbance that might ooour. The guards at each police station throughout the ci y were doubled and mounted polioemen patioiled the streets, but there was not the slightest disturbance. In faot, the tranquillity of the city now-a-days isabsolutely unparalleled. Death of Mr. Stiliano Platidis,
We regret to announce the death of the director cf the Greek Hospital at Alexandria, Mr. Stiliano Platidis, which occurred early on Saturday morning from heart disease. The funeral took place on Saturday afternoon, at 4.30 o’c.ock, and was largely attended by all classes of the Helleuio community of Alexan­dria, by whom the deceased was held in high esteem.
The Kaiser’s Birthday.
Ou the ocoasion of the forty-seventh anni­versary of the birthday of the Kaiser, a grand fete will be given by the German colony at Cairo at 3.30 p.m. at the German school. On the following day there will be a thanksgiving service at 10 a.m. in the German Churoh in the Ismailia quarter, at 11 a.m. a reception at the German Agency, at 7.30 p.m.'a banquet at the Continental Hotel, aud at 9.30 p.m. a fdte at the German Club.
Capture of Noted Murderer.
This morning a Bedouin was brought into Alexandria from Mariout by an escort of the Sudanese polioemen who gn^rdL. over that district. The man is a notorious malefao’or aud some three years ago committed a murder under most atrooious circumstances in the ueighbourhood of Kafr Dawar. He esoaped into the desert and was sentenced in his absence to penal servitude for life. About two years ago he committed another savage murder in Mariout aud again he managed to evade the clutches of the police and was onoe more sen fenced in his absence to penal servitude for life. However, the police kept watch f ir the man aud yesterday he appeared at Amrieh, where he was rec >gnised and captured.
An Excellent Example,
In view of the increase in the oost of living in this country, the excellent example set by Messrs. Walker and Meimaraohi, Ltd., is one which should be extensively followed. The firm have on the occasion of the New Year increased the salaries of their employes by
amounts which in the aggregate totals several hundred pounds. The appreciation that this humanitarian action, which is due to Mr. C. Moimarachi, has met with at the hands of the employees benefited, cannot be better expressed than by reproducing the letter which they have addressed to their popular managing director:—
Monsieur,
Par la prtaeuto nous vonons d’abortl vous souhaiter nos vteux Iob plus sinecres pour uno uuudo hourouso ot Hnris-taiilo <«t vous oxprimcr on memo temps nos plus vifs romerciementg ot touto notro reconnaissance pour les augmentations <juo vounavez bion voulu approuver.
Los augmentations quo vous nous avoz accortkos viennent juste a propos pour fairo face a la ohortv do tout cornmo aliinoutation etloyor, etc.
Vouilloz, monsiour 1'odministratour, agr&raveo nos remerciomonU antioip^ss nos sentiments de profond fespect

THE ELECTIONS.
LANCASHIRE’S FREE TRADE VOTE.
( Gazette’s Special Service. )
London, Monday, Jan. 15. The feeling of the country with regard to the elections is unmistakable. It is tbviously tired of seeing Balfour batting and is more inclined to give the other side an innings rather than fight it out on any defiuiteisiue, although Mr. Balfour has been oroshingly defeated. Lanca­shire has undoubtedly again championed the polioy ot free imports, which is not onnataral, considering the present great prosperity of the Lancashire trade

cell.p: NEW LIBERAL ORGAN.
London, Monday, Jan. 15.
A new first olass Liberal paper, “The Tri­bune,” which has been in preparation for some “me, was appropriately issued thia morning.
According to an offioial report published to­day at the Ministry ofthe Interior an explosion which caused some loss of life took place on the night of the 12th inst. at Boulac Dacrour station.

It appears that shortly after 8 p.m. train No. 254 entered the station and an emplo­ye, lifting the tarpaulin which covered an j open truok containing a number of barrels of benzine, discovered that one of thete barrels was on fire. The truck was immediately un- oonpled aud was being shunted on to a siding to enable the lailway officials to extinguish the flames when a series ot explosions took plaoe.
Fifieen men were injured, two of whom have sinoe suooumbed, and the condition of several ot the others is reported to be critical.
An enquiry is being held into the causes of the aocident.
The Connoil of Ministers which met on Saturday morning under the presidency of H.H. the Khedive took the following de­cisions :—

list.item: To transfer the following officials: Mahmond Bey Rasmi, Suh-Moudir of Minieh, to Assouan to replace Ahmed Bey Mustapha, resigned ; Hafez Bey El Kharbontti, Sub-Mondir of As­souan, to be Sub Governor of Ismailia, to re- plaoe All Eff. Gelal el Din, appointed Mamonr of the Public Security section in Gharbieh.
To appoiut Mahmond Pacha Fehmi to be a member of the Superior Council of the Wakfs Administration.

To oonvoke the Ghirgeh provincial coun­cil on the 20th inst. for the eleotion of two of its members and their proxies to form part of the Committee of Appeal in questions referring to the reassessment of taxes.
To approve of the grant of a subvention ofL.E. 3,000 to the Orwat El Woska Sooiety for the construction of an industrial school at Alexandria.

cell.p: Other decisions deal with questions of expropriation, publio buildings, etc., and with the lists of officials recommended for honours by the various State Administrations, which were all approved.
AIDA.

On Friday night Aida was played before a fall and enthusiastic house, whioh was generous in its applause and showed an amazing want of artistic taste in demanding encores at the wrong moment A particularly flagrant instance of this ooourred in the 3rd act,when Amonasro, having hurled his undntifal daughter to the ground, was enoouraged to repeat the perfor­mance by the plaudits of the greater part of the audience and very properly deolined. At other times a pause of a few bars in an aria was utilised by members of the dress oirole to “bis” the soloist. Those who knew the opera better hissed them into silence, but the result­ing din more than once prevented a good piece of orchestral mosio from being properly heard The next musioal reform required in Cairo is the abolition of the “encore” bat we shall never get it

Now for the opera and artistes. Aida opened badly, the artistes were nervous, the audieuce cold till the oousecratiou soene. Henoeforth the singing improved steadily. Signora Lavin as Amueris and Sig. Amato (Amonasro) were really good. Signora Ross (Aida) improved greatly after the first aot bat there seemed to be a certain want of tone in her higher notes. Sig. Nioolaon. (Ramfis) sang with the papal dignity that befitted a high priest of Ra, but

Sig. Langobardi was QDeven—poor at the opening, better in the third act, and rather weak in the fourth, in which he teemed to have overstrained his voice. Pharaoh was rather stiff, while the corps du ballet were positively wooden ; their movements were characterised by a complete absence of grace and their training appeared to have been utterly neglec ted. On the other hand, the chorus was really good and the orchestra highly satisfactory.

The gallery behaved as the gallery does fiction of the knockabout sort. Such perfor mances are amusing in narrative but peculiarly trying in real life. There were no unnecessary delays, nothing, in fact, that could justify a section of the audience in behaving like the habitues of an eighth-rate music hall
POLICEMAN’S EXCESS OF ZEAL.
(From our Correspondent).
Suez, Sunday.

The Mahmal reached Snez yesterday at noon by a special traio, whioh was sainted from the fort with 21 gnns. The procession through the principal streets of Suez started at 2.30 p.m. It was exceptionally well organized this year and was headed by H E. the Governor of Snez on hot o’»- ck. The prooession consisted of Cavaby. Infantry, Artillery with field and Maxim guns, and a military band, all of which presented a brilliant aspeot.

Iu spite of the good order maintained, a regrettable inoident occurred while the Mahmal was passing the Italian Consulate On the verandah of the consulate there was a French lady, who, seeing the Holy Carpet for the first time, was endeavouring to take a snapshot of it with her camera. A oonstable, however, on seeing the lady taking a photo, oalled out to her to go into the house, and as the lady did not take any notice of his absurd demands, he began to throw stones at her, thus drawing the attention < f the considerable number of natives following the carpet, who might very possibly have followed his example. Fortunately, the Italian Consol. Mr. Deperais, happened to be on the verandah also at the time, and prompt­ly sent his janissary to take the oonstable’s number, and order him to withdraw, which he did after insulting the consul by shootiog ont "inta min,” eto.
Another photographer who took np his stand rear the station was stoned by the mob.
The Mahmal is leaving Snez to day by the Khedivial steamer Rahmanieh.

div.p:
THE PRINCES’ CASE.
The hearing of the action brought by the Khedivial Princes against the Credit Foncier has been postponed till March 12.

cell.p: (From our Correspondent).
Assouan, Monday.

H.R.H. Prince Charles William of 8weden and suite, who have been staying for two days at the Cataract Hotel here, have left Assouan for Lnxor, where rooms have been reserved for them at the Luxor Hotel.
(From our Correspondent).
Assouan, Saturday.
His Royal Highness Prinoe Leopold of i Battenberg and suite are expect e I back at the Cataract Hotel on the 15th. inst, where his Royal Highness will stay till the end of the season.

The hotels are now pretty fall, and owing to the delightful weather many tourists are postponingiheir departure. A Sports Committee has been formed at the Cataraot Hotel for the purpose of arranging sports af all kinds,— Gymkhanas, regattas, croquet and tennis tournaments, and also indoor entertainments, sach as dances,theatricals, ooncerts.eto, for the benefit of the visitore. A paper ohase will take plaoe this week and the oommittee announoe from now that the grand annual fanoy dress ball of the Cataraot will be held on the 29th inst. Passengers of the S. S. Rameses the Third are to be invited.
(From our Correspondent).
Suez, Sunday.

The S.S. Gera and 8tuttgart, belonging to the N.D.L., and chartered by the Russian Government, arrived at Suez this morning fall of Russian prisoners from the Far East. They both entered the Canal in the afternoon.
(From our Correspondent).
Snez Sunday.

The hired transport Dnnera, from Hong- Kong, Shanghai and Colombo, is dne to arrive at Snez early to morrow morning honnd to Malta and Southampton with homeward-bonnd troops. ___________________________

The budget of the Wakfs Administration for 1906 shows an increase of L.E. 68,000 in the receipts, which are expeoted to amount to L.E. 384,500, while the expenditure amounts to L.E. 328,675, showing an increase of L.E. 68,509. L.E. 12,000 will be spent on the inorease of the pay of the employes and L E. 15.000 on the creation of an inspectorate— a reform suggested by Harari Pacha’s recent report.
A. S. C.
We are asked by the Clerk of the Course to give notioe that the race course will be open for trial gallops on Wednesday morning next, the 17th inst., from six to ten.
The Moss liner Rameses arrived at Liver­pool on Saturday morning.

p.hi: The 8. 8. Sailor Prinoe arrived at Man­

cell.p: CASE SENT BEFORE SUPREME COURT.

Thomas Fraser Thomson was oharged before Mr. Alban at H.B.M.’s Consular Court, Cairo, on Saturday morning with embezzling I the sum of L E. 267 belonging to Messrs. Thos. Cook and Son (Egypt), Ltd. The first witness was Mr. Harrison, who stated that he knew accused, who was employed as a cle*k at Messrs. Cook’s engineering works at Boulac, where he had bsen working since Jane. He stated that in consequence of information I received he had taken steps to proseonte aooused. The details of the oase were known to I Mr. Sibhald, Messrs. Cook’s superintending I engineer.

Mr. T. K. Sibbald stated that he had known I aooused for some six months as his chief corresponding olerk. On Friday week he fonnd Thomson missing from the office in the morning and asked Mr. Reynolds, the Assistant I Superintendent, where he was. In oonseqner.ee I of oommunioations reoeived from Mr. Reynolds and a bowab he went down himself to Messrs. I Cook’s dahabeah, where he fonnd aconsed in I bed with all his olothes on and very dronk. I He oonld make no coherent statement. On I the following day aoonsed did not appear and on Monday witness reoeived a wire from Port I Said in whioh aoonsed said he was reonperatiDg 1 and would oome to work on Tuesday. As he did not appear witness oommnnioated with Messrs. CaDgosand Co., oontraotors, and asked them if they h.d reoeived railway polioies for explosives and whether they had paid any snms to Thomson. He fonnd that a cheque on the Anglo-Egyptian Bank had been given to aoonsed in payment of an account and oashed by aooused at the Anglo Egyptian Bank.

Mr. Cangos deposed—with a certain vague­ness as to dates—that the accused came to see him re an order he had given to Me-ww. Cook for detonators and gelignite tor the Fayoum. He oame again with an aooonnt and a oheqne in payment was signed by witness’s partner Kassim Bey Hosni and made ont by witness’s olerk Pericles Kytioaki.

Selim Abassi, oashier of the Anglo Egyptian Bank, Cairo, recollected the aooased’s oalling at the Bank. Aoonsed asked for a cheque made payable to Messrs. Cook. When oheq ies were presented at the bank the usual course followed was to hand the oheque over to tl • acoonntant to see whether the signatory had oredit and the oheqne was then passed on to the oashier for payment. This oheque was made payable to Thos. Cook & 8on or bearer. Witness gave aooused £250 in banknotes, the rest in cash. In answer to a question pat by the aooased, witness stated that the num­bers ot bank notes were never kept. Notes P and cash were given to any persons, even : Barberine servants, presenting cheques that ’ were in good order.
Perioles Kytioaki, Mr. Canges’ aooonntant,

list.item:
stated that he took an order tor gelignite and detonators, and had to telephone to Messrs
Thos. Cook and 8ons asking them to hurry uj matters. On January 5 aooused o&me with tw<

cell.p: f railway polio'es and a reoeipt for the valu<

list.item: of the order, £274 16.5, in pencil. He corro " borated M. Cango’s statements in the writinj 8 i ont and signature of the cheque.

cell.p: a | The oonrt then adjourned pending the ar rival of Mr. Reynolds. On his arrival Mr Reynolds gave evidence corroborating Mi

list.item:
Sibbald’s statements, and identified the pri
I soner’s handwriting on the reoeipt and in th , endorsement of the oheqne oashed at th

cell.p: Anglo-Egyptian Bank.
Evidence of arrest was given and aoonse
was committed for trial before the Saprem
3. Consular Court Mr. Harrison requested th Coart to fix the amount of bail as low as po sible, sayiDg that he should be very sorry t think that the prisoner might be kept in priso
0 longer than was necessary pending trial. Ba n was allowed in two sureties of £50.

div.p:
DISTURBANCE AT DAMANHOUR.
Oar Damanhonr Correspondent reports that a disturbance took plaoe in that town yester­day, a conflict having arisen between a num­ber of Jews and the natives, on the occasion of the celebration of a Jewish feast. Some hun­dreds of persons took part in the affray, and many were injured in the oonrse of the melde, which might have assumed much more serious proportions, but for the timely interference of the polioe. It appears that the aggressors were the natives, whose attitude was not at all reassnring

cell.p: (From our Correspondrnt).
Akhmin, January 11.

The Holiness Movement Churoh of Canada held a oonv'-ntion in this town from the 5th to the 7th inst, inclusive, in oonneotion with the dedication of their first ohuroh in Egypt It was largely attended from the opening until the closing service.

The main body cf the new choroh has a seating capacity of abont six hundred, and there is also a gallery accommodating more than two hundred. Every place waa packed fall and numbers had to stand outside.
There were six missionaries present together with a large sbff of native preachers. One of the chief characteristics of the meetings has been prayer,which continues almost unceasingly day and night
WHAT THE WOMEN WORE.

Pressure on onr spaoe on Saturday prevented ns from dealing with the social aspect of Friday’s 8kye Meeting at the K. 8. C. grounds, Ghezireh. In spite of its being oue of the smaller meeting* there were many people present, and it was by far the smartest meeting we have seen this season. Among others we noticed :— General Bollock, Sir William Garatin, Hon. L. M. Iddings, Baroness and the Miles de Villebob, Major and Mrs. Herbert Gapt and Mrs. Maclean, Sir John and Lady Rogers, Capt. and Mrs. Bailey. Major and Mrs. Parsons, Major and Mrs. Delavoye, Gapt. and Mrs. Rome, Goles Pacha, Mrs. and the Misses Co'es, Dr. and Mrs. Armstrong, Dr. and Mrs. Nolan, Mr. and Mrs. Stoat, Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Hewitt, Mr. Allan Jo-eph and Miss Joseph, Mrs. French, Omar Bey Saltan, Iahak Bey Hussein, the Hon. G. Yorke, Mr. Garter Wilson, Major Herbert, Gol. Aylmer, Mr. Dicey, Mr. Foreatier-Walker, Mr. Satow, Mr. Reid, Capt. Gillson, Mr. A. L. Moberlev, Mr. Garter Wil8nn, Mr. Rnmbold^ Mr. Oroville, and Gapt Bartlett.

8ir Augustus and Lady Hemming were there, the latter in dark bine with lace appliance, while Miss Hemming was in a cream aoooraion- pleated skirt and pretty lace-trimmed blouse. Gapt and Mrs. Morgan were also present, Mrs. Morgan in a lovely Parisian frock of laoe with narrow applications of pale grey doth set as flounoes on the skirt, and composing the smart little coatee and three-oorned nat. Mrs. Wynne was in white olotb, inset with ooarse ! net and trimmed with silk braid, lines of gnaging drawing the fulness of the back into the waist. Her nat of felt had the brim lined with fine straw and was tilted high on one Bide bv a caohpeigne of brown velvet and adorned

on the other side by sweeping plames. Mrs. Roylewasin dark bine, the corsage slashed with mnoh laoe, and Mrs. Maclean was in white oloth, the pleata of both bolero and skirt fastened down by small buttons, buttons also forming the trimming at the hem of the skirt and on the elbow sleeves. The Miles de Villebois were in dark blue and wore black hats, and Mme. de Martino was gowned iu brown and had a couple of peacock s feathers in her toque. Mrs. Parsons was also in brown, and Mrs. Claude Rome was iu white with a large round hat of rose colour. Miss de Bilinski was in a long blue oloth ooat and skirt, and Miss Lampson, who brought her ynnng brother, was wearing a long coat and skirt of broderie anglaise made over pa’e green. Mrs. Rom had on a gown of gTey and green shot taffatas, with applications of green oloth and a short ooat, also of green, and Miss Begg was in an embroidered heliotrope ordpe de-Chine made with many thick oordings. Mrs. Armstrong was iu white serge and Mrs. Valentine-bmitn was wearing a deep bine silk, trimmed with much laoe. Mrs. Bailey was in blue oloth embroidered with heliotrope and she had a long heliotrope scarf round her neck. Her hat was of fine Leghorn trimmed with a raching of heliotrope and knots of pale blue velvet Mm. Nungovioh was in soft brown ordpe-de-Chine with an enormous hat of brown with shaded feathers of Sevres blue. Miss I Nungovioh was in white. Mrs. Whittaker bad on a lovely ohampagne-ooloured oloth with ornamentations of tine blaok braid on the skirt,
the braided corsage heingpieroed and laid ovar coarse lace. There were bands of black satin at the elbows and waist, and also glimpses of
I pale bine veiled with laoe both on the sleeves I and in the front of the oorsage.

WHAT THE MEN WORE. Complaints having reached ns that the gar­ments of the sterner sex have not reoeived snffioient attention in onr columns, we are happy to inform onr readers that we have obtained at great expense the services of a correspondent who, while writing under a psendonyro, will be reoognised by those "in the know” as one of the most brilliant contributors to the "Tailor and Cotter.” Our correspondent may at the start be les v oapable of identifying the nameroQs well-dressed individualities who throng onr race courses than a resident, bat we are oertain that onr readers will forgive any slight inaconraoies cf this description.

Sir John Rogers, very handsome in grey and white, was ohaperoning Mr. 8tout, and very nice Mr. Stoat 1 oked in a gold-rimmed eye-glass and patent leather boots. The Hon. F. Lindley’s trailing Newmarket ooat relieved by a bine velvet necktie waa mnoh missed, bat we shall doubtless hear that it has been

row.cell: limitated by the olnb men of Tokyo, among whom a read ion against the flowing sleeves and elaborate coiffure of the Samurai modes has reoently manifested itself Mr. Allen Joseph brought his bevy of popular bourse rangers and Mr. George Royle looked every inoh his surname. Gapt. Maolean and Gapt Bailey looked smart in out-away coats trimmed with cigarette ash, and Gapt fiigge, who is always so much admired, was as well dressed as ever in grey pants neatly tucked into bis sockp, grey shirting, white sweater, and a oeintnre of M. G. C. colours. Mr. Peokitt, in silver grey, reoeived mnoh attention, and Capt Morgan, Mrs. Morgan’s bridegroom, deserves more than passing notioe. Sir Malcolm Me Ilwraith was in grey with a diamond pin in his oorsage, and Mr. Donlop wore a pink rose and was as neatly ooiffe as ever. The latest bride­groom, Mr. Much ell, was present drape! in darkblne, relieved by tonohes of white at the neck and wrists. Sir Horace Pinohing, always

so well dressed, looked very handsome in a grey Hombnrg hat and a white waist coat with much passamenterie trimming, and Doctors Keatirga and Madden were as well turned out as ever. Dr. Clark wore the latest creation of Davies Bryan with a fol

cell.p: pink satin tie tooxea inio me deoolletage, and Mr. Friend’s fine figure was well set off by a or6pe-de-Chine aqnisontam. Msjor Delavoye looked as handsome as ever in a tweed sao ooat made very fall at the baok and with the latest toad-in-the hole shape in tweed hats. Mr. Carter-Wi’son wore a princess '-made con­tention of the fashionable Vermouth-ard bitters colour, with a new ribbon on his chip straw hat. Mr. Amos wore his usual smile and a bl«ok bowler hat. Among othprs we noticed Mrs. Lao Hunter, Sir Gorrinaand Lady Midas. I Mrs. Pom-onhy de Tnmkvns, the Emperor Mntehitsn. Mr. Adam (of Ghezireh) and Mrs. Eve (of Old Cairo). '

cell.hi: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
H.H. Prinoe Abbas was among the gers who arrived thi-i morning by the Austrian Lloyd steamer. 4

row.cell: It is announced that the Earl and Countess of Carnarvon will pay a short visit to Egypt while on their way to Colombo.

cell.p: The Bishop of Hereford is on his way up to Khartoum, where he intends to visit his sod, Capt Perceval, of the Egyptian Camel Corps.
Vice-Admiral Sir George Atkinson Willis is one of the latest arrivals at the Grand Conti­ nental HoteL
Col. Augustus West-Hill, C.B, is staying at Mena House..

p.hi: Lady Wise, wife of Sir W. Lloyd Wise, D.L., is staying at the Grand Hotel Helonan.

row.cell: Sir Charles Thomas Dyke Acland and Lady Acland are staying at the Hotel d’Angleterre.
Col. Cuthbert George Collingwood and his wife are staying at Ghezireh Palace Hotel.

cell.hi: Sir Alfred for Luxor.

row.cell: Pease has left the Hotel do Nil

cell.hi: 8ir. Vincent Corbett leaves for
Wady Haifa to-day by the 6.30 p.m. express.

row.cell: M. de la Bouliniare attended mass in the Syrian Catholic church at Fagallah on Sunday.

cell.hi: Crookshank Pacha is leaving Khartoum to*
day for Gondokrto. He will return to Khar* foam on February 11.
Mr. St Johi, Marmeworth, a younger brother of the newly created Baron, is staying at 8hepheard’s Hotel.

row.cell: The common l of the Army Service Corps

cell.p: towards the latter part of next month
Mr. Charles J. Alford, the well-known min­ing engineer, is coming out to Egypt by the P. & 0. S.S. China and expects to be at the Continental Hotel, Cairo, on the 24th inst

cell.hi: Mr. Speir, of the State Railways, who left for England last week to aot as “beat man”
to Mr. Paget son of the Chairman of the
Midland Railway Company, will
be returning about the 25th of this month.
